author: Mike Kelly
title: Is another stock market crash about to hit the UK and should we be worried?
text:
News Is another stock market crash about to hit the UK and should we be worried? As the FTSE 100 hits a record high we ask if the share price rise will continue in 2017 or collapse and plunge us into a financial crisis Share Queues outside Northern Rock in Newcastle - September 2007 (Photo: Ian Clyne) Share Get daily updates   Thank you for subscribing!   
Is the UK due a stock market crash which could see North East pensions and investments severely hit? 
The question is beginning to be asked at a time when the FTSE 100, which reveals the value of the 100 largest companies listed on the London Stock Exchange, has hit an all time high of around 7,300. 
However before bust comes boom and there are some who fear it might come sooner rather than later. 
Many North East workers have seen their pension pots soar by around 20% in the last 12 months if they were linked to the fortunes of the UK’s ‘blue chip’ companies. 
However, history has taught us some bitter lessons. 
In 2008, the FTSE 100 fell 31% in value compared to 2007 following the banking crisis at the centre of which was Northern Rock. 
Local memories are still raw about the sight of customers of the North East based financial institution queueing round the block to take out theri cash. 
So, should we be afraid? John Newlands 
John Newlands, Head of Investment Companies Research at Brewin Dolphin’s Newcastle office thinks not. 
He said: “People shouldn’t be concerned by the fact the FTSE 100 is at an all time high. It always goes up in the long term, although some might find that hard to believe, it has never failed to pay and will never fail to pay in the future. 
“It was at around 6,900 back at the time of the Millennium so the current figure is only 400 points up on that in 15 years.” 
He said problems can start when, for example, people start “chasing trends”. 
This was highlighted by the bursting of the dotcom bubble - fuelled by the extraordinary and irrational popularity of online companies which caused the FTSE 100 to fall from 6930 at the end of 1999 to 3287 by March, 2003. 
The soaring value of shares provides a major boost to people saving for their old age. 
Former pensions minister Baroness Ros Altmann, said recently: “It’s a great start to 2017 for people’s pensions that the markets are so strong now. 
“Of course markets can go down as well as up but with the economy doing well the £300billion added to the stock market in recent months is bound to be good news for people’s pensions.” Customers queue outside the Northern Rock on Pilgrim Street, Newcastle upon Tyne 
Despite prophecies of doom following Brexit in June last year, after a brief blip the markets roared back. 
Experts say one of the key reasons is that many of the companies, 70% in fact, that make up the FTSE 100 trade in many markets beyond the UK. Read More MP Chi Onwurah on the North's industrial heritage and a strategy to keep post-Brexit Britain wealthy 
This meant the plunging pound after the June 23 vote has been hugely advantageous for them – boosting their earnings and helping with their share prices. 
The stock market has also been boosted by the election of Donald Trump as the next US president. His economic stance is clear, he intends to pour money into the US economy, which should have a knock-on effect on world markets. 
This means shares in the US have soared, and many believe the good fortune will spread around the world meaning a boost to FTSE 100 shares with international interests. Read More 
Mr Newlands said as long as you have a diversified range of managed funds it offers protection from the turbulence in the market. 
However he added: “It’s always helpful to review your portfolio and get good advice.” Like us on Facebook
